Context:
* The George Brown College offers a three-year advanced diploma program in Game Programming.
* Students will learn technical skills in C and C++, artificial intelligence, 3D graphics, and more.
* Classes take place at George Brown – Waterfront Campus, with evening courses possibly required.
* Students who start the program in January (winter term) may be required to attend classes during the summer months (May to August).
* Technology requirements include a personal computer with at least 8 GB RAM, a 256 GB SSD Hard Drive, a Quad-core i7 2.5GHz processor or better, a video card with 4GB RAM and OpenGL 3.2+/DirectX 11/12 support, and a webcam.
* Graduates of the program may work in various areas of the digital game industry such as software or hardware development, publisher, ISP and game portal development and maintenance, website development, distribution middleware and tool provider, production servicer, and content/IP owner.
* The Canadian video game industry contributed over $3 billion to the Canadian economy and provided 20,400 FTE jobs in 2015, with an increase of 31% and 24% respectively since 2013.
* Global and Canadian industry growth is expected to continue into the future.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Game – Programming Program T163 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The text provides information about the growth of the video game industry in Canada, with 472 active studios located primarily in Quebec (29.4%), British Columbia (27.1%), and Ontario (22.9%). There is a BSc (Honours) Computer Games Design program available at the University of Gloucestershire for graduates of Game Programming. The curriculum for this program includes courses such as Introduction to Programming, Advanced Programming, Artificial Intelligence, Data Structures & Algorithms, and Game Production I-VI. Additional courses mentioned include 3D Graphics Programming, Mobile Game Development I, Console Game Development I, Multiplayer Systems, and Game Engines I-III. The program also includes General Education Electives in various semesters and Professional Workplace Competencies in Semester 5.

Context: Fees for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates are subject to change for international students. The program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet the eligibility criteria. Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), and either grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students can take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or consider upgrading to achieve the required credits. College or university credits may qualify applicants for course exemptions, and international students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific requirements. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. Contact information for the School of Computer Technology: 3 Lower Jarvis St., Room 260, Phone: 416-415-5000 (ext. 4287 or 3129), Email: computertechnology@georgebrown.ca or game@georgebrown.ca, and Office hours: Monday – Friday: 9 a.m. – 4 p.m. The Program Co-ordinator's contact information is: Phone: 416-415-5000 (ext. 4232) and Email: arichard6@georgebrown.ca.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Game – Programming Program T163 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The George Brown College offers a Game – Programming (T163) advanced diploma. Some of its graduates have found jobs in notable studios like Ubisoft and Rockstar. One group of students, No Sleep, formed their entity before graduation and produced a game that won several awards, including Best Student Showcase at Digifest 2018. Their member Mark Miller advised current students to attend classes regularly. Jack Wiebe, a Game – Programming student, worked on a research project with Vitruvian Sport Systems to develop Zone360 - a digital training platform for soccer that uses virtual reality and mobile technology. The College's international students can contact representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry through the International Contact Us page. The Game – Programming program takes place at Casa Loma and St. James Campuses. For more information, visitors can sign up for an information session or campus tour, or explore related programs such as Computer Programming and Analysis (T177), Computer Systems Technology (T147), and Computer Systems Technician (T141). The phone numbers for contacting the College are 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
